issues.description: The problem statement and UML require SealSaloon to have a constructor that accepts a String (the saloon name) but both the provided template usage and the solution implement/use a no-argument constructor. This mismatch will confuse students about the expected constructor signature and whether they must store a name. The problem text explicitly states "The constructor takes the saloon name as a String parameter for identification purposes," and the UML shows +SealSaloon(String), yet the solution's SealSaloon has public SealSaloon() with no String parameter and the example Main uses new SealSaloon() (no-arg).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor signatures consistent. Either (A) update the solution and template examples to provide a constructor SealSaloon(String name) that stores the name (and add a getter), matching the problem statement and UML; or (B) change the problem statement and UML to require a no-argument constructor if a name is not intended. Preferred: implement public SealSaloon(String name) and store a private final String name with a public getter.

issues.description: The problem statement asks students to add getters for all private fields and indicates the constructor should accept a saloon name (implying a private name field). The solution's SealSaloon lacks a name attribute and therefore lacks the corresponding getter. This contradicts the explicit instruction to provide getters for all private fields and the constructor requirement for a name parameter.
issues.suggested_fix: Either add a private final String name field to SealSaloon (set via a SealSaloon(String name) constructor) and provide a public getter getName(), or, if the name is intentionally omitted, update the problem statement to remove the instruction about providing a constructor parameter and the expectation to add getters for that field.

issues.description: Constructor signature mismatch for SealSaloon: the problem statement (UML and text) requires a constructor SealSaloon(String) that accepts a saloon name, but both the provided template usage (Main.java) and the solution implementation define/expect a no-argument constructor (SealSaloon()). This creates mapping confusion for students: the problem text tells them to implement/expect a constructor taking a String, while the starter code's example and the reference solution use or provide a no-arg constructor. Students may be unsure which constructor to implement, whether they must store a name field, or whether tests expect a String parameter.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the constructor API across artifacts. Either (A) update the solution and template to provide/expect public SealSaloon(String name) (add a private name field and a getter) so it matches the problem statement, or (B) update the problem statement to allow/describe a no-argument constructor (SealSaloon()) and remove the requirement to pass/store a saloon name. For minimal disruption keep the existing no-arg constructor but add an overload public SealSaloon(String name) so both the example in Main and the problem specification are satisfied.
